												I've got to be honest, the first time I played this game I was disappointed.  The combat, both on horseback and on foot, just felt off.  In addition, there is almost no story.  And the graphics are definitely outdated.  So why the positive review?  This is a game that grows on you, but only if you give it time.  The early stages where you have nothing are frustrating, as you can't do much and are easily defeated.  But if you can weather this period, the game opens up as you build up supplies and equipment and soldiers.  In addition, the combat becomes much more intuitive as you spend time with it.  You are soon able to best larger armies due to your skill level, as well as the quality of your equipment and soldiers.  Unfortunately, it's at this point that the game feels a bit broken.  The whole game revolves around several factions that own various towns and are at war with each other, and you generally align yourself with one of these factions.  No matter how well you equip your crew at this point in the game, you almost always encounter insurmountable odds when you face any of the opposing factions in combat.  For example, you might be limited to a party of 60, but will regularly encounter parties of opposing factions that range from 100-200.  Worse yet, even if you're able to best such a large party, it's almost a given that the opposing faction will have another party or two in the area, each with 100+ soldiers.  It never feels like your faction supports you as much as other factions support them.  In addition, conquering all of a faction's towns seems next to impossible as the towns are dispersed over quite a large area on the map.  While you might conquer several towns in one area, it could take you several in-game days to travel to the next area to conquer that faction's remaining towns.  Meanwhile, those initial towns you conquered have been conquered by one of the game's other factions, as you typically spread yourself thin trying to attack so many areas.  Overall, I know that I've pointed out several flaws with this game so far.  That being said, I feel like these issues don't detract from the game so much overall, as addressing them would make the sequel that much better.  I really enjoyed this game, but a sequel that addressed my issues would be worth a lot of money to me.  This game was good, but I look forward to checking out more from this franchise.  I would give this game a 7.5/10.

												I've been gaming for 30+ years and over that time I've played a lot of games. From my experience, Mount & Blade offers a unique gaming experience. Not quite like anything else I've ever played. There are some similarities to familiar games, such as shades of the Total War series, but stark enough differences that they really cannot be compared. Mount & Blade in my opinion is fairly easy to learn, but does take some skill with action type fighting to be mastered. If you enjoy strategy games with a turn based feel, mixed with real time combat, in a non-linear world; then Mount & Blade may just well be your cup of tea. I was looking for a somewhat decent strategy game that would run on my gutless business laptop and I have to say I was not expecting as good of a game as it turned out to truly be. It's got enough meat in the vanilla campaign to keep most people busy for at least 100 hours I would speculate, though I personally have already invested 200 hours into my first vanilla campaign and can see it dragging out another 100-200 easily. Beyond the vanilla game, there are apparently many mods made for this game as well. Some appear to be quite promising and I will surely be giving at least a few a spin. All in all I would highly recommend this game. I bought it on sale and was skepticle, but having now played it, I would have paid the full price and not felt shorted in any way. Well worth the money imho. + Cheap.+ Very low system requirements - should run well on most machines.+ Time consuming single player campaign (I'm not interested in a game if it can be beaten in less then 48 hours of actual gameplay).+ Easy to learn, yet unique combat system that is both fun and requires skill to master.+ High replayability due to massive amount of community mods available.- AI is not the greatest and can be stomped fight after fight once you learn it's flaws. I'm talking I have decimated a larger opposing army almost by myself. Siege AI is almost worse, you can take any city with 10 men once you have learned their flaws. They don't fare any better trying to take a city from you either. 10 men could hold off thousands if you know what you're doing.OVERALL 9/10 AND I WOULD DEFINITELY RECOMMEND TO ANY TRUE STRATEGY FAN.

												Mount & Blade is a game that wants to be it all and while the lack of polish makes it fail in a lot of places the solid design behind it all makes it succeed in many more.At it's core Mount & Blade is a hack and slash game, and by that I don't mean one button for light swing, one button for power swing. Using either mouse or keyboard you can select a myriad of different attacks and blocks depending on the weapon you're using as you engage in high intensity melee's with hundreds of opponents.You play the game in two modes, the world map and the battle map. The world map is where you walk your hero across the land, recruit soldiers, buy weapons and goods and find bands of enemies to fight. When you go into battle you are transported onto a procedurally generated battle map where you get you fight your enemies with whatever weapons and soldiers are at your disposal. Although both of these modes are plagued with a number of bugs and rather noticeable lack of polish the core of the fighting remains fun and challenging and makes you forgive the flaws you may encounter.Graphically Mount & Blade is nothing too impressive. It's full of rough edges and flat surfaces and you know it's an indie title when you play it. The sound is similarly lacking and not much to talk about.But despite all it's flaws this is just one of those few rare games that manages to live through a low budget, bad tech and broken features through a strong and simple core mechanic. The fighting is excellent and there are enough mods available to remedy many of the problems on the world map. Although this is a title that will never quite feel like it should be classic it still manages to hold a strong place in your memory.Although this is an excellent game that I throughly enjoyed playing it is not one I would recommend you buy these days simply because the Warband standalone expansion is pretty much just an updated version of this.

Instead of turn base, when you stop in the map, the game pauses. Once in battle though you can choose to just tell your troops what to do or get involved yourself. Choice is yours. For beginners, it may look like dynasty warriors but don't just rush in lol. It's not how that works here, that's not how any of that works. 												This game is amazingly fun for about 50 hours, if for no other reason than it's probably the only time you'll get to kill things from horseback. The game really reaches its peak about 20/30 hours in, when your character is strong enough - and your army large enough - to take on each realm's king and his massive personal guard. The only real issue is that there's too much sandbox: your goal is to "make a name for yourself." Which would be fine and dandy if you were allowed to become a king and unite the country; however, you're specifically forbidden from doing this. You're told flat-out at the beginning of the game that you can't become king. Kind of obnoxious. Also, you can't kill empires, as noblemen live forever and will swarm cities until they can re-establish their clan. So one you reach that point where a normal RPG would reward you with huge tracts of land, you instead export your character and start all over again, but this time with insanely high skills that let you fight just about anything and really screw with the early-game dynamic. Almost makes up for that whole not-being-a-king thing.

												Mount & Blade. What an epic game! Yes, it's graphics are horrid, and yes, there are a few small bugs left in there, but wow, I'm currently clocked in at 63 hours, and I know that I've at least a few more days to go until I'm satisfied with this game, and even then, I'll probably make a new character just to follow another king.This game is amazing, terrific, wonderful, and much more! Combine the combat of Chivalry and the overworld trading business with the flash game "Caravaneer", and this is a lot better yet. After you get through the slow tutorial, it's a challenging, yet EXTREMELY rewarding climb from nothing to king, one that 63 hours in, I have yet to achieve. The feeling of training peasants to fight bandits, then watching them go at it right afterward is epic and makes you feel like you've made a significant difference to their lives. The first army you take on and defeat leaves you gasping for breath, sweat on your forhead, and prideful of your newfound superiority. Now we get to move on to the big guns: Taking fortresses and fortefied cities! And that's a LOT more fun than it sounds!There is one big problem that has to be addressed, and that is the games difficulty. I had no problem with difficulty because I had all the options set to easiest (so that I feel like a boss), but I'm on "22% difficulty". If you are someone who can't stand playing on Easy, then this might be a bit rough for you and your armies.I cannot reccomend this game enough, ecspecially to those who love build-your-army type games! Once you have a feel for all the weaponry (small changes make big differences), and what race of soldier can accomplish what, you can progress rather well, and this game has been nothing but fun all the way!But it! 												Overall: so much fun! You get a great combination of action in the medieval combat, strategy in the larger scale battles, and role-playing game classics such as choosing alliances and missions, leveling up, and suiting up.With that said, the role-playing aspect couldn't be considered truly complete on its own. Your personal relationships with lords, for instance, does indeed evolve somewhat and have an impact on the options available to you, but the relationship mechanisms in place are a little shallow. This part of the game sort of comes across as a roleplaying sandbox and only a stick to dig with. Combat and looting also suffer some issues, but overall the combat system is pretty satisfying (though you'll see what I'm talking about when you're trying to pick up weapons in the tournaments). A variety of fairly viable combat styles are available to your character, though you'll usually have to adapt to the context of the battle. Speaking of the battle contexts, you're offered a number of different scenarios, from open battles on the field to raiding throne rooms to laying siege to cities or castles. You can thus get a nice taste sword and shield battle atop a wall as well hit-and-run with mounted archery in the field. These styles and contexts also flow nicely out of the nature of your army and their background, with the Khergit, Swadians, Rhodoks, Vaegirs, and Nords differing significantly in their typical strategies. For many people that enjoy these games, the tactics surrounding match ups between these factions is the heart of what makes the game unique.Anyway, overall awesome. I look forward to trying the Warband expansion where some things will be fixed and some content will be added.

												Life is short if you're not on a horse: the game.Holy cow is this game addictive!  The very first thing I noticed was that the graphics are a bit dated; there are sprites and menus that could use some work, and some of the animations have some glitches here and there.  It just doesn't have the polish and motion capture sparkle of modern games and I thought that would translate into me hating it.  But, the actual game play is addictive and exhilerating.Start off with the fact that this game is a sandbox.  You are not the chosen one, the world does not revolve around your actions, your story is exactly what you make it and nothing more.  This means you travel where you want, do what you want and you weather the consequences.  I got the feeling that I was a very small cog in a very big machine and for once I felt like a game gave me a sense of perspective.The strategic map offers it's own set of challenges as forces of varying strength roam the world looking for fights.  You have to pick your battles, and keep your eyes open for opportunities.  Then when you get on the battlefield, it is all hard charging and bloodshed and life just being awful for footsoldiers.  Honestly, I've gotten to the point where the biggest threat to me is a cramp in my axe arm, and I feel a little bad for those poor schmucks on the other side of the map.  The action could use some tinkering, but I've been having so much fun playing it, I can't say that it is really broken.I bought this game on sale and got my money's worth.  It's worth more than that.  I've had a lot of fun!

												Best combat on horse or foot that I've played so far. Realistic combat mechanics, both on foot and mounted; the game's strong point is a simulation of combat on horseback.Visually impressive even though this game is already a few years old. The environment rendering like the dynamic lighting of day and night cycles and occasional weather effects like fog or rain are convincing. Graphic details are very much customizable.Game is very flexible and non-linear; you are free to do as you please; stay neutral or pick sides, hunt bandits or do quests, in any order and at your own pace. Issue tactical commands during 1st person battle or strategic commands on the world map. Strategic commands are only available after joining a faction and after being elected as the marshal.Use your marshal appointment to mobilize a huge battalion and engage on a war path OR NOT. NPC AI in battle and pathfinding is adequate. If the lords are not mobilized, they will most likely patrol or do their own thing; they may also occasionally attempt to besige a castle but they will not coordinate with other lords unless you're not the marshal but just one of the house lords, in which case, another marshall will coordinate the army. So if you don't want the game to end so soon, don't coordinate a castle siege.Though character class is non-existent, role-playing elements are quite extensive. Distribute attributes & skill points to your preferred style of play. Weapon proficiency increases through usage. Neither magic nor alchemy is needed here; the setting of this game is medieval fiction rather than mythological fantasy but it has enough interesting elements, depth of gameplay & replayability to draw you back and try something new.Ahh, before I end this lengthy justification of a recommendation, I do have a few gripes about M&B, albeit minor ones. One is that morale of the party gradually goes down over time; the bigger the party the faster it declines and morale only gets a major boost after a major battle is won, this makes it virtually imperative to look for trouble to keep the troops happy even though they are always paid on time and adequately supplied with a variety of food types. If the troops do not get their fix of adrenaline they may eventually desert your party. Luckily bandits roam about all the time, you just have to be fast enough to nail them. As you might have guessed by now, the other thing is that troop maintenance is high, so you got to constantly fight in tournaments, look for quests, sell loot, sell prisoners to the slave market, or collect taxes but by far the most lucrative way of earning money is placing bets in the tournaments, looting enemy villages or extorting from enemy caravans. No rest for the weary.Despite its aggravating tendencies, this game does integrates aspects of role-play, strategy, action and simulation equally well in a neat polished package and this kind of inclusive gameplay I have not seen nor played before, hence my recommendation.

												At first glance, M&B seems like another bland Medieval Combat game. It was designed by a Turkish Couple and, let's be honest, isn't the prettiest game in this generation. As the age old mantra "Never Judge a Book By It's Cover" states, however, Mount and Blade is much more than meets the eye. The game is a full simulation of a land dominated by several kingdoms, each one vyying for domination. In the center of the chaos is you; a lone sellsword whose only advantage is indomitable will and a (possible) noble background. The game allows you to do whatever you please; swear fealty to a king, ascend the ladder of nobility through marriage and political gaming, raise an army and siege castles and strongholds, compete in tournaments for honor and cash, or just spend your days ambushing caravans and living off of the spoils. There's no wrong way to play the game and no matter what method you choose, you'll have fun. The game also boasts a fantastic combat system and several mods. Get it.

												Mount & Blade is a fantastic action-strategy-RPG with the best horseback-based fighting engine I have ever experienced.  Battles can grow very large with 32+ infantry and horse based units racing around in a chaotic bloody mess... with you experiencing the action from an "over the shoulder" perspective.  Strategy elements are managed via a large regional map from which you move your army from place to place accepting quests or following your own agenda.  "Heroes" in you army can be levelled up, like you, and you can purchase new gear or just use the loot from your kills.  Some will think the grafx are a bit primitive, but honestly you will not notice after landing a few headshots galloping across the field.  Also the game does not lead you down any particular path... you will need to explore a bit and just try things.  Eventually you won't be able to stop playing.  The best indie-game ever.

												Pretty much a sandbox RPG, which is not really as great as it sounds.  The quests are completely dull and the entire story amounts to some exposition and the odd feature that your enemies prefer to capture you and take your stuff rather than simply kill you so that you won't take revenge in the future.It's a good experiment in seeing how many fiefs or territory you can acquire, or whether you can outfit your guy in the most expensive armor before he bites the poverty bullet or you get too bored with it.I played with this game for many hours, which is to say, i experimented with it.  The combat is a mildly interesting wargame about conserving troop morale with the power of food, blocking and annoyingly aim-centric swinging that avoids combos and feels more like D&D due to how much easier it is to miss the opponent instead of actually hit them or get blocked by them (except when you're on foot), making sure you have enough horses and the right weather and time of day to optimize your travel speed across the map graphic, verbally telling off your follower NPCs for arguing with each other, and a bunch of other stuff that is really only interesting in concept rather than presentation or follow through.The only real merit, is of course, mounted combat against forces on foot, cheesey castle sieges that aren't worth much after the first few (or 10 or so, if you're me), and the concept of the game itself.FINAL SCORE: 55.

Here Mount & Blade's beauty lies in it's simplicity.  Let your NPC allies draw fire while you stab, slash and bludgeon your way through the enemy ranks one left-click at a time.  Aim with your cursor and time every block and right-clicked parry or bait a big swing out of an enemy with a well-timed sidestep or circle-strafe; you're in complete control.  While settings do allow the user to enable auto-directional blocking and tone down damage levels to make combat more forgiving, the real joy comes out when you crank up the difficulty.  One misstep, a slight hesitation in bringing up your shield, a misjudged attack or an errant arrow could mean the difference between victory and defeat.  THIS is how first person melee combat should play.

												Mount & Blade is a bit more like the newer Elder Scrolls games in that, despite the fact that it has all the skills and stats that we come to expect from an RPG, all of the combat is real-time and the player is in control of the action.  As a result, combat feels a lot more fluid and less clunky then menu-based combat, and it feels like more varied experience as a result.  But to drone on about combat for too long would seem unfair, as that is only one small part of M&B's design.  The amount of variaty and choice the game presents you with is impressive.  It gives you this choice not through the means of dialoge options, (which are a part of the game, but are not a big feature) but by presenting you with varied ways of playing.  When a game can be just as fun playing as a merchant with a high trade skill instead of playing as a lord commanding warrior bands, you have done somthing very, very right.  Villiages provide more mild quests for farmers and traders, while kings and cities can offer up challenging and exciting quests for those looking for adventure.  The quests themselves, however, are generally pretty bland.  Most of them are randomly generated fetch/kill/deliver tasks.  I can't count on both hands how many times I ended up delivering a message or collecting taxes.  I would have liked for a few more scenarios for these quests, and perhaps even some non-random quests initiated by certain in-game events.  The presentation is somewhere in the middle of the scale.  While enviornments can be very impressive, characters are *just* realsitic enough to make thier creepy, empty-faced stares downright unsettling.  While I understand how out of place it would have felt, I would have perfered slightly more caricatured character models to keep them out of the uncanny valley.  Music, on the other hand, feels just right, and fits the fantasy world like a glove, even if it is mostly ambient.  But overall the asthetics make for a very nice fantasy atmosphere.       Mount and Blade is a game that is hard to get into at first due to a steep learning curve and lack of any good tutorials.  But once you finnaly get through the initial phase of confusion, you will find a true gem of a game underneath.

												A lot of people here are saying that Warband was an improvement in every regard, but I disagree. There are a couple of things that the original Mount & Blade did better.- More complex level design allows for more tactical combat, with the exception of the plethora of invisible walls within these levels, specifically at castles. If I'm going too close to a ledge, I'd prefer to fall off and learn the hard way, rather than being blocked from falling at all.- A condensed map makes campaigns move much quicker, and reduces a lot of the tedious running around, not to mention the fact that I can get to situations before they finish. Nothing quite angers me in Warband such as getting a notification for an event happening on the other side of the map, only to get there and find out I just missed it.That being said, there are a few issues which I've noticed here that have been fixed in its sequel.- The journal does not keep a record of everything that Warband does.- Combat occasionally feels sloppy. Unresponsive controls and weird hit detection can make some fights, particularly melee, take too long.- Getting in and out of a merc contract or vassalage without ruining one's reputation (with both leaders and opposing factions) is extremely difficult.Of course, Warband ironed out these problems and added some graphical upgrades, a bigger map, and another faction. It improved on the original in almost every way, but I found it worth a few hours of my time to explore this game's superior castles, towns, and villages, at least until I ran into that problem of a gimped reputation system.

												A lot of people here are saying that Warband was an improvement in every regard, but I disagree. There are a couple of things that the original Mount & Blade did better.- More complex level design allows for more tactical combat, with the exception of the plethora of invisible walls within these levels, specifically at castles. If I'm going too close to a ledge, I'd prefer to fall off and learn the hard way, rather than being blocked from falling at all.- A condensed map makes campaigns move much quicker, and reduces a lot of the tedious running around, not to mention the fact that I can get to situations before they finish. Nothing quite angers me in Warband such as getting a notification for an event happening on the other side of the map, only to get there and find out I just missed it.That being said, there are a few issues which I've noticed here that have been fixed in its sequel.- The journal does not keep a record of everything that Warband does.- Combat occasionally feels sloppy. Unresponsive controls and weird hit detection can make some fights, particularly melee, take too long.- Getting in and out of a merc contract or vassalage without ruining one's reputation (with both leaders and opposing factions) is extremely difficult.Of course, Warband ironed out these problems and added some graphical upgrades, a bigger map, and another faction. It improved on the original in almost every way, but I found it worth a few hours of my time to explore this game's superior castles, towns, and villages, at least until I ran into that problem of a gimped reputation system.
